description: Alteration of loup, from Old Norse hlaupa (“to leap, jump”). See leap. Cognate with German laufen (“walk, run”), Danish løbe, Dutch lopen (“walk, run”), Norwegian løpe (“run”). Doublet of leap.

entries.meaning: An easy pace with long strides.
examples: Hares have larger, leaner bodies, longer legs, and longer ears than the true rabbit. They also run with a lope instead of a hop. It is thought that they developed this more stream-lined body and swifter gait from running on the plains  […]

verbs.description: lope (third-person singular simple present lopes, present participle loping, simple past and past participle loped)

entries.meaning: To travel an easy pace with long strides.
examples: He loped along, hour after hour, not fast but steady and covering much ground.
he that lopes on the ropes
